title: `eth_getLogs` may not return expected results
body:
Using Nethermind `1.9.22-0-dc76facfa-20201118` with Ethereum 2.0 beacon client Lighthouse v0.3.5, Lighthouse shows these error messages:

`Failed to update eth1 cache             error: Failed to update eth1 cache: FailedToInsertDeposit(NonConsecutive { log_index: 107764, expected: 107763 })`

The Nethermind logs show the RPC calls, but I am unsure where to look to find the issue.

```
eth1_1    | 2020-11-18 16:06:24.2096|Executing JSON RPC call net_version with params
eth1_1    | 2020-11-18 16:06:24.2186|Executing JSON RPC call eth_chainId with params
eth1_1    | 2020-11-18 16:06:24.2292|Executing JSON RPC call eth_getBlockByNumber with params latest,False
eth1_1    | 2020-11-18 16:06:24.2413|Executing JSON RPC call eth_getBlockByNumber with params 0x3996d6,False
eth1_1    | 2020-11-18 16:06:25.5135|Executing JSON RPC call net_version with params

eth1_1    |   "address": "0x07b39f4fde4a38bace212b546dac87c58dfe3fdc",
```

I have seen this on mainnet as well now:

`Failed to update eth1 deposit cache     error: FailedToInsertDeposit(NonConsecutive { log_index: 1328, expected: 0 }),`

Edit: Mainnet trouble might be a red herring, it's still filling in "OId Bodies". That should be done on the 20th, US time afternoon to evening. I'll check again then. Goerli trouble is very real.

So there are multiple ranges of blocks where nethermind seems to be returning less logs than geth. 

The rpc request I used was
```
curl --location --request POST 'http://localhost:8545' \
        --header 'Content-Type: application/json' \
        --data-raw '{
        "jsonrpc":"2.0",
        "method":"eth_getLogs",
        "params":[{"address": "0x07b39F4fDE4A38bACe212b546dAc87C58DfE3fDC", "topics": ["0x649bbc62d0e31342afea4e5cd82d4049e7e1ee912fc0889aa790803be39038c5"], "fromBlock": "0x38de50", "toBlock": "0x38e238"}],
        "id":1
        }'
```
Here's a diff between the same request on a goerli geth node vs goerli nethermind(using @yorickdowne 's nethermind db) https://gist.github.com/pawanjay176/69a44e921754789ea89666eb0ea5e550

geth returns 16 logs and nethermind returns 12 for the same request. 

Edit: also added the count diff for a few more ranges of blocks in the gist.
@LukaszRozmej ?

Just to have that in here and not just Discord, here's how Nethermind was started for this test:

```
 entrypoint:
      - dotnet
      - /nethermind/Nethermind.Runner.dll
      - --Init.BaseDbPath
      - /var/lib/nethermind
      - --Init.WebSocketsEnabled
      - "true"
      - --Sync.DownloadBodiesInFastSync
      - "true"
      - --Sync.DownloadReceiptsInFastSync
      - "true"
      - --Network.DiscoveryPort
      -  ${ETH1_PORT}
      - --Network.P2PPort
      -  ${ETH1_PORT}
      - --JsonRpc.Enabled
      - "true"
      - --JsonRpc.EnabledModules
      - "net,eth"
      - --JsonRpc.Host
      - 0.0.0.0
      - --JsonRpc.Port
      - ${ETH1_RPC_PORT}
      - --JsonRpc.WebSocketsPort
      - ${ETH1_WS_PORT}
      - --Sync.FastSync
      - "true"
      - --config
      - ${ETH1_NETWORK}
```

where ETH1_NETWORK is goerli and the ports are 30303, 8545 and 8546 by default, respectively and in order.
I'm experiencing the same issue while trying to hook up Rocketpool Lighthouse to Nethermind.
we are looking at it already, top prio, thanks

I've been experimenting with an OldBodies and OldReceipts barrier of 3,740,000 on Goerli. When doing so, this call did not return expected results:

```
eth1_1                      | 2020-11-20 11:26:45.3735|Executing JSON RPC call eth_getLogs with params {
eth1_1                      |   "address": "0x8c5fecdc472e27bc447696f431e425d02dd46a8c",
eth1_1                      |   "fromBlock": "0x3988db",
eth1_1                      |   "toBlock": "0x398cc3",
eth1_1                      |   "topics": [
eth1_1                      |     "0x649bbc62d0e31342afea4e5cd82d4049e7e1ee912fc0889aa790803be39038c5"
eth1_1                      |   ]
eth1_1                      | }
```

And Lighthouse shows:

```
ERRO Failed to update eth1 cache             error: Failed to update eth1 cache: FailedToInsertDeposit(NonConsecutive { log_index: 100031, expected: 0 })
```

Changing the barrier to 1 or removing the barrier entirely did not change that. It could be entirely co-incidental; it's also possible that specifying a barrier initially makes it more likely a DB issue occurs.

I'm seeing it on main. Sync is done there now, so it wasn't an artefact of "wait for sync to complete".

`Failed to update eth1 deposit cache     error: FailedToInsertDeposit(NonConsecutive { log_index: 1039, expected: 0 })`
That's awesome, great news! I shall test, and I *really* am looking forward to removing the dire warnings about Nethermind from my eth2-docker tool. Thank you for sticking with it!
@LukaszRozmej would I have to resync my Nethermind node to fix the issue?

@pawanjay176 first use v1.9.39
Secondly you need to do one of two:
1. Resync
or
2. Enable --Sync.FixReceipts true.
Is this `--SyncConfig.FixReceipts true`? It's not in the documentation... is it definitely SyncConfig instead of Sync?
@pk27734 I am just fixing the docs - it is Sync.FixReceipts

> @LukaszRozmej would I have to resync my Nethermind node to fix the issue?

@pawanjay176 no need to resync

> That's awesome, great news! I shall test, and I _really_ am looking forward to removing the dire warnings about Nethermind from my eth2-docker tool. Thank you for sticking with it!

@yorickdowne this is fixed now in 1.9.39

Do we still need the following?

`--Sync.AncientReceiptsBarrier 11000000 --Sync.AncientBodiesBarrier 11000000 --Sync.DownloadReceiptsInFastSync true`

@pk27734 I think if you remove the barriers fast sync might download old bodies and receipts on restart. 

--Sync.DownloadReceiptsInFastSync true should be by default.

Sync from scratch worked, fixing did fix a whole bunch of receipts but then Lighthouse still complained of missing data. Switching Nethermind over to the "from scratch" DB made Lighthouse happy. You've got a copy of the repaired DB to see what was going on there. Initially repaired with a PivotNumber of 3,730,000, then 3,600,000, which caught a few more in the 3,720,000 range. The failing Lighthouse query on the repaired DB starts at 3,775,587

Tip for anyone getting the error "Failed to update eth1 cache": It is possible to easily clear the cache via flag: 

`lighthouse bn --eth1-purge-cache ..other args..`
